channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: She Was in Labor. Floodwaters Were Rising. Then the Boat Tipped Over.
item.description: A pregnant woman who drowned in Vietnam was one of at least 114 people killed in record-breaking floods that have pummeled the country’s central coast.
item.dc:creator: Chau Doan and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Vietnam News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo from the state news media showed villagers navigating floodwaters with the help of rescue workers in central Vietnam’s Ha Tinh Province on Tuesday.

item.title: In Xi’s Homage to Korean War, a Jab at the U.S.
item.description: China is commemorating the war with a barrage of nationalistic propaganda. “They smashed the myth that the American military was invincible,” China’s leader said.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: An event marking the 70th anniversary of China’s participation in the Korean War at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: Pope Francis’ Views on Same-Sex Civil Unions Were Cut From a 2019 Vatican Interview
item.description: A Mexican broadcast company says Francis made the comments to its correspondent more than a year ago, and people close to the company say the Vatican then edited them out.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Natalie Kitroeff
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Speculation swirled around the Vatican about whether the pope’s statements had been cut from an interview more than a year ago.

item.title: For Italy’s Masked Rap Diva, an Era of Face Coverings Poses a Dilemma
item.description: Myss Keta, the mysterious Queen of the Milan Night and an authority on life behind the surgical veil, was on the brink of celebrity. Now, everyone looks like her.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Myss Keta, center left, the Italian rapper, performance artist and L.G.B.T.Q. icon, posing for a picture with fans in Milan.

item.title: In Iran, Aydin Aghdashloo Is Accused of Sexual Misconduct by 13 Women
item.description: The #MeToo movement has hit a nerve among Iran’s women. Now accusations against a politically connected celebrity artist are testing the movement in a sexually conservative society dominated by men.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Aydin Aghdashloo, an internationally acclaimed artist with ties to the ruling elite, faces accusations of sexual misconduct over a 30-year span.

item.title: E.U. Says Veggie Burgers Can Keep Their Name
item.description: The European Parliament voted on Friday on proposals that would have banned products without meat from being labeled burgers or sausages.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Carsten Koall/EPA, via Shutterstock; Daniel Roland/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Europe’s main farming lobby group called it “cultural hijacking” to put a vegan burger, right, in the same category as a beef burger.

item.title: A Radical Cleric Ignites an Islamist Resistance in Afghanistan
item.description: The cleric’s supporters in Herat are enforcing harsh Shariah law reminiscent of the Taliban’s. Women are alarmed, and the government has been able to do little.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino, Najim Rahim and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Friday prayer at cleric Mawlawi Mujib Rahman Ansari’s mosque in Herat, Afghanistan, last month.

item.title: ‘We Are Not Going to Lie Down’: A Coronavirus Revolt in England
item.description: How a Liverpool gym led a local rebellion against the government’s inscrutable rules.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Cavern Quarter in Liverpool, northwestern England, where the Beatles made their name. Many of the pubs and clubs in the area are closed because of new coronavirus restrictions.

item.title: How Bolivia Overcame a Crisis and Held a Clean Election
item.description: A presidential race that many feared would end in uncertainty or violence concluded quietly, allowing Bolivians to hope that a year of turmoil and threats to democracy may be behind them.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: Luis Arce, the handpicked candidate of the former president, Evo Morales, will be the next president of Bolivia.

item.title: U.S. Embassy in Turkey Issues Security Alert and Suspends Services
item.description: The embassy said it had received “credible reports” of potential attacks and kidnappings aimed at Americans and other foreign nationals in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: At the Hagia Sophia in Istanbul. The U.S. Embassy urged American citizens to exercise caution at malls, office buildings and other sites where foreigners gather.

item.title: Outcry in Philippines Over General’s ‘Warning’ to Female Celebrities
item.description: Accusing a women’s rights group of ties to Communist rebels, the general told an actress she could be killed if she associated with the organization.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: Catriona Gray, center left, in Manila in 2018, the year she won the Miss Universe pageant.

item.title: Edward Snowden, in Russia Since 2013, Is Granted Permanent Residency
item.description: The former intelligence contractor still hopes to return to the United States. But the Russian authorities have given him the right to stay in Russia indefinitely.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Jorg Carstensen/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden speaking via video link at a conference in Berlin last year. Recent changes to Russian law helped him win permanent residency.

item.title: Libya’s Two Main Factions Agree to a Cease-Fire
item.description: The two main factions in years of civil war that have drawn in Russia, Turkey and other regional powers signed an accord at the United Nations in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce and Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The historic center of Benghazi, Libya, lays in ruins after years of conflict.

item.title: The Final Debate
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of high school students watched the debate in a backyard in Haddonfield, N.J.

item.title: Swimming to Sanity in Melbourne’s Lockdown
item.description: As the city creeps out of one of the world’s longest lockdowns, the reopening of outdoor pools grants a partial freedom.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Yan Zhuang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlton Baths in Melbourne.

item.title: Trump and Biden’s Final Debate: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: This debate on Thursday night between President Trump, left, and Joe Biden was noticeably calmer than the first.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Many of the worst outbreaks in the U.S. right now are in rural areas.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Schoolchildren Seem Unlikely to Fuel Coronavirus Surges, Scientists Say
item.description: Researchers once feared that school reopenings might spread the virus through communities. But so far there is little evidence that it’s happening.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Temperature checks at an elementary school in Smithfield, R.I.

item.title: Russia Poses Greater Election Threat Than Iran, Many U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Russia’s hackers appeared to be preparing to sow chaos amid any uncertainty around election results, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Eve Edelheit for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers in St. Petersburg, Fla., on Monday. Intelligence officials have expressed concern about Russian efforts to sow chaos around American election results.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Goldman Sachs will pay billions in 1MDB scandal.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A field hospital in an exhibition center for coronavirus patients in Prague. The Czech Republic is under partial lockdown closing schools, shops, restaurants and limited public activities until November 3. The Czech Republic has reported almost 15 000 new cases yesterday.

item.title: The worst virus outbreaks in the U.S. are now in rural areas.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby

item.title: Poland Court Ruling Effectively Bans Legal Abortions
item.description: The decision, which cannot be appealed, halts pregnancy terminations for fetal abnormalities, virtually the only type currently performed in the country.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: A protest against abortion restriction in Krakow, Poland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Neo Rauch’s New Rule: ‘Never Answer a Critic’
item.description: Neo Rauch’s provocative statements drew him into a nasty public dispute. He now wants to put that behind him.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neo Rauch in his studio in Leipzig, Germany, this month. Sixteen of his new works are showing at Eigen + Art Gallery in the city.

item.title: Copenhagen Mayor Resigns Amid #MeToo Wave in Denmark
item.description: Frank Jensen admitted to harassing numerous women over decades. His case is part of a gathering confrontation in the country over sexual misconduct.
item.dc:creator: Martin Selsoe Sorensen
item.media:description: Mayor Frank Jensen of Copenhagen resigned on Monday. “I’m terribly sorry for the women I’ve offended through my 30 years in politics,” he told a newspaper.

item.title: New state unemployment claims in the U.S. fell below 800,000 last week.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families at a food bank in Vallejo, Calif., on Wednesday. Every week, more Americans join the ranks of the long-term unemployed — those out of work for more than 27 weeks.

item.title: Vatican Extends Deal With China Over Appointment of Bishops
item.description: The agreement calls for China to formally recognize the pope’s authority within the church, while the Vatican in turn recognized the legitimacy of bishops previously appointed by Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: An Easter Vigil at a Catholic church in Shanghai in 2018. The Vatican has portrayed the deal over bishops as a step in a long journey to better provide for its faithful in China.

item.title: Saad Hariri, Lebanon's Ex-Prime Minister, Could Again Lead the Country
item.description: Saad Hariri, who stepped down amid antigovernment protests last year, could return as the head of the government amid multiple crises.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Saad Hariri, center, Lebanon’s former prime minister, arriving at the office of President Michel Aoun on Thursday.

item.title: The Latino Gender Gap
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Latinos for Trump rally in Miami on Sunday.

item.title: The virus has dimmed the Friday night lights of football in Texas.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Verónica G. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Palmview High School football team last week in Palmview, Texas.

item.title: Hurricane Epsilon Swerves by Bermuda After a ‘Wobbly’ Northwest Turn
item.description: A tropical storm warning for the island was lifted as the storm passed “well east of Bermuda.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Air Force Reserve, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Hurricane Epsilon as seen Wednesday by an Air Force Reserve hurricane hunter team over the Atlantic Ocean.

item.title: In Munich, a Theater’s Ambitious New Era Starts Mid-Pandemic
item.description: Barbara Mundel takes over as artistic director of the Münchner Kammerspiele, lately perhaps the most consistently exciting playhouse in Germany.
item.dc:creator: A.J. Goldmann
item.media:description: Martin Weigel in Jan-Christoph Gockel’s production of “A Youth in Germany,” based on the novel by Ernst Toller, at the Münchner Kammerspiele.

item.title: OSHA is under fire over its regulation of meatpacking plants.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Alex Mcintyre/The Greeley Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Beatriz Rangel, center, at the grave of her father Saul Sanchez, a JBS employee who died of Covid-19 in April after an outbreak at the meat processing plant in Greeley, Colo. The plant was later cited for safety lapses.

item.title: ‘These are everyday people who are dying’: A study offers a new picture of the lives lost to the virus.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:description: U.S. flags were placed on the National Mall in Washington last month when the country’s death toll from the coronavirus passed 200,000.

item.title: Trump in North Carolina: ‘All you hear is Covid, Covid, Covid, Covid, Covid.’
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns
item.media:description: President Trump during a campaign rally in Gastonia, N.C., on Wednesday.

item.title: Forgotten on the presidential campaign: schools in crisis.
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough
item.media:description: An elementary school in the Bronx. The challenges of schooling during the pandemic have not been a major presidential campaign theme.

item.title: Europe Wonders if It Can Rely on U.S. Again, Whoever Wins
item.description: America’s deeply polarized politics have marked foreign policy, too, undermining Washington’s authority and reputation for reliability.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times

item.title: Nigeria Protests, Coronavirus, Pope Francis: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Security forces in Nigeria open fire on protesters.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Nigerian state security vehicle moved through a crowd of protesters in the Lagos area on Tuesday.

item.title: Richard Grenell Pursued Talks of Maduro, Power Change in Venezuela
item.description: A close ally of President Trump quietly met with an associate of President Nicolás Maduro, whom the United States does not recognize as the leader of Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Richard Grenell’s trip surprised senior administration officials, including the secretary of state.

item.title: The C.D.C. updates its definition of ‘close contact’ in relation to infection risk.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: Close contact means being within 6 feet of an infected person for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, the C.D.C. says in its updated guidance.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Alaska is emerging as a possible test case for what winter may be like in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: A Dozen Protesters in Nigeria Reported Killed by Security Forces
item.description: Nigerians are stunned after police and soldiers opened fire on protesters against police brutality. The largely peaceful demonstrations have grown into a challenge for the government.
item.dc:creator: Shola Lawal and Monica Mark
item.media:description: A Nigerian state security vehicle moved through a crowd of protesters in the Lagos area on Tuesday.

item.title: France, Waging a Crackdown, Honors a Teacher and Depicts a Plot in Beheading
item.description: Two teenagers were paid about $350 to identify a teacher later decapitated outside his school. As the nation mourns, officials move against what they see as militant Islam.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France called the slain teacher a “quiet hero” at a memorial on Wednesday.

item.title: South Korea Tries to Quell Anxiety Over Flu Shots After 13 Unexplained Deaths
item.description: Health officials say there is no link between the deaths and the flu vaccines. But the deaths, after two recent vaccine recalls, have raised safety fears among the public at a critical time.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Shoppers in Seoul’s Hongdae district on Sunday. Officials worry that concerns over the safety of flu vaccines could undermine efforts to fight coronavirus and develop a vaccine for that pandemic.

item.title: No, mouthwash will not save you from the coronavirus, despite that study going around.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:description: Scientists say that since the study didn’t recruit any human volunteers to gargle the products in question, the findings have limited value for the real world.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Trump’s business pursuits in China.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Will Dudding
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times

item.title: Thailand’s Leader Offers End to Crackdown on Pro-Democracy Protests
item.description: Prayuth Chan-ocha, who withdrew an emergency decree on Thursday, has called for mediation by a weakened Parliament. But protesters are demanding his resignation.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
National Council for Peace and Order (Thailand)
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-democracy activists marching to the prime minister’s office on Wednesday during a protest in Bangkok.

item.title: Why Protests in Nigeria Are Aimed at SARS, a Notorious Police Unit
item.description: Africa’s most populous country and biggest oil producer has been convulsed by protests that started with anger over police brutality and have now broadened, drawing worldwide attention.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone and Megan Specia
item.media:description: A Nigerian state security vehicle moved through a crowd of protesters in the Lagos area on Tuesday.

item.title: Manslaughter Charge Urged for Israeli Officer in Killing of Autistic Palestinian
item.description: Palestinians assail the failure to recommend a murder charge in the case, which has become a cause célèbre in the fight against police brutality.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A mural depicting Iyad al-Hallaq on the separation wall in Bethelem in the West Bank. The unarmed Palestinian man with autism was killed by a police officer in May.

item.title: In Azerbaijan, Pain and Loss Drive Fever for War With Armenia
item.description: As the country’s soldiers advance in the conflict with Armenia, every “liberated” territory is celebrated and tens of thousands of refugees plan their return to lost lands.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

item.title: In Shift for Church, Pope Francis Voices Support for Same-Sex Civil Unions
item.description: The comments, shown in a new documentary, are the strongest yet from a pontificate that has taken a more tolerant and inclusive tone.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving for the weekly general audience at the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: Asbestos, a Quebec Mining Town, Will Change Name to Val-des-Sources
item.description: The Quebec town is home to one of the world’s largest former asbestos mines. Residents voted to rename the town Val-des-Sources, or Valley of the Springs.
item.dc:creator: Marie Fazio
item.media:description: What's left of the Jeffrey Mine in Asbestos, Quebec, soon to be called Val-des-Sources.

item.title: The New Trustbusting
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Larry Page, left, and Sergey Brin at Google headquarters in 2004.

item.title: Hurricane Epsilon Is 10th of the Season
item.description: The storm is the 10th hurricane of the season. A tropical storm warning is in effect for Bermuda.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Afghanistan Stampede Over Pakistan Visas Leaves at Least 12 Dead
item.description: At least 12 people died as thousands crowded a soccer stadium. Many were seeking medical care in Pakistan, which recently eased its pandemic border restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Zabihullah Ghazi and Fahim Abed
item.media:description: Afghan men strained to get the tokens required to apply for Pakistani visas in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Jean-Claude Van Damme Helped Save a Puppy
item.description: The action star Jean-Claude Van Damme intervened to save a Bulgarian dog from euthanasia after Norway said it had been imported on a fake passport.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
